Taller de arranque nacional y talleres de socializaci√≥n a nivel territorial desarrollado 1er taller sobre conflicto gente ‚Äì fauna y tr√°fico de vida silvestre desarrollado Taller de Capacitaci√≥n para la Identificaci√≥n y Manejo de Flora Decomisada, Registro de Huellas de Mastofauna y Nociones para la Gesti√≥n del Conflicto Gente ‚Äì Fauna desarrollado Primer Seminario sobre Delitos en Contra de la Vida Silvestre desarrollado Procesos de equipamiento para el proyecto (c√°maras trampa, veh√≠culos, equipos de comunicaci√≥n y computadoras, etc) lanzados

target.comment: Este proyecto se orienta a disminuir las amenazas: Cacer√≠a comercial, Tr√°fico de vida silvestre, Conflictos entre seres humanos y fauna silvestre y la fragmentaci√≥n y destrucci√≥n de h√°bitas -Marco de manejo adaptativo para orientar la implementaci√≥n costo-efectivo de la conservaci√≥n de la vida silvestre -Emplazamiento de la conservaci√≥n de la vida silvestre en √°reas protegidas claves -Acciones comunitarias para desarrollar medios de vida sostenibles para reducir las presiones de cacer√≠a de subsistencia insostenibles en tres paisajes determinados. -Fortalecimiento y aplicaci√≥n del sistema de control (marco normativo) para reducir la cacer√≠a ilegal -Planes de Desarrollo y Ordenamiento Territorial PDOT incorporan normas para la protecci√≥n de h√°bitats clave que permiten la conectividad y la dispersi√≥n de la vida silvestre -La conectividad funcional en los paisajes de importancia para la dispersi√≥n de la vida silvestre

actual.comment: -Diez t√©cnicos socio ambientales han sido capacitado y han realizado ya cinco muestreos en cada paisaje, enfocado en las especies terrestres, cr√°cidos y primates. -Dos campers adquiridos para la atenci√≥n emergente de animales silvestres. Hasta el momento han sido atendidos un total de 102 animales por parte del equipo de veterinarios del Proyecto. -Capacitaci√≥n dirigidas al personal de la UPMA, MAE en territorio y a t√©cnicos de GADs (CONGOPE). Se impartieron talleres enfocados en los temas de ‚ÄúMulticulturalidad pol√≠tica, gesti√≥n ambiental y manejo de conflictos socio ambientales‚Äù. A trav√©s del Programa de Capacitaci√≥n Aula Verde y en estrecha colaboraci√≥n con el CONGOPE y la AME, se desarroll√≥ un programa espec√≠fico de capacitaci√≥n dirigido a t√©cnicos del MAE (responsables de vida silvestre) y de los GADs (t√©cnicos de gesti√≥n ambiental del CONGOPE) enfocado en la ‚ÄúGesti√≥n de la Vida Silvestre‚Äù que incluy√≥ a 60 participantes. -Delimitaci√≥n y propuesta de declaraci√≥n de un sitio RAMSAR y la creaci√≥n del √°rea de conservaci√≥n ‚ÄúCordillera Oriental‚Äù en la Provincia del Carchi (16.000 ha), y realizar√° el estudio de tenencia de la tierra como uno de los requisitos previos. -WCS complet√≥ el proceso de validaci√≥n de los mapas de conflicto, para lo cual utiliz√≥ como insumo la informaci√≥n generada en el estudio del diagn√≥stico socioecon√≥mico. -La gesti√≥n ha apoyado el desarrollo de algunos materiales para su pr√≥xima publicaci√≥n, entre estos est√°n: i) Plan de Manejo de la Reserva Ecol√≥gica El √Ångel; ii) Lineamientos T√©cnicos y Estrategias para el Manejo de Conflictos entre la Fauna Silvestre y las Actividades Agropecuarias; iii) Gu√≠a T√©cnica y Operativa para el Control del Comercio y Tr√°fico de Fauna Silvestre en el Ecuador; y iv) Gu√≠a para la identificaci√≥n de especies de fauna silvestre sujetas al tr√°fico, y comercio ilegal de carne de monte. Lineamientos para su manejo emergente. -Tres estudios hecho sobre la produccion de cacao fino de aroma, Recopilaci√≥n y an√°lisis d

result.title: Objective
result.description: Ecuador‚Äôs PA system applies landscape approaches to increase its effectiveness for conservation of globally important wildlife

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Status of target species
O1. Maintenance or increases in abundance of target species in target landscapes.
See Table 18 for species by landscape

baseline.comment:
IUCN Red List status gives some indication of threat status
See Table 18 for IUCN categories by species

target.comment:
In all target PAs, corridors and buffer zones
- 0% negative change in abundance of species with low reproductive rates
- 10% increase in abundance of those with high reproductive rates
See Table 10 for landscapes and targets per species

actual.comment:
The project‚Äôs implementation of the program of biological monitoring at landscape scale has begun, starting with field sampling to obtain baseline information on the five selected landscapes sites (1. -The Pambilar Wildlife Refuge - Cotacachi Cayapas low zone, 2.- Cotacachi Cayapas Ecological Reserve high zone - El Angel Ecological Reserve, 3. - Cof√°n Bermejo Ecological Reserve - Llanganates National Park, 4.- Cuyabeno Corridor - Yasun√≠, and, 5. Podocarpus National Park). For this fieldwork, the document "Protocol for Recording and Monitoring Presence of Populations of Priority Species through a Landscape Approach in Selected Areas" had previously been developed.
To implement this monitoring, a group of ten Social - Environmental Technicians, from the United Nations Volunteers‚Äô Program, was selected, hired, trained and equipped. 200 camera traps were acquired, along with other basic equipment for field sampling, in which the active participation of staff of rangers and technicians working in the seven protected areas covered by the project was given.
Additionally, the process was started by developing a comprehensive financial sustainability strategy for the management of wildlife in the project area; which includes strengthening the management committees of PAs, as well as plans for community wildlife management and the expansion of protected areas within the country.
To fulfill this indicator, several communication elements and awareness to the community governance wildlife management were considered to be included.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Status of target habitat
O2. Increases in coverage of vegetation in corridors/buffer zones of all 5 target landscapes of value for habitat and connectivity for target wildlife species

baseline.comment:
In December 2012, 3,659,252ha of forests and other areas of native vegetation were under protection through Socio Bosque (331,565ha), as Forest Heritage, Protection Forests or as part of the sub-system of private, provincial or community reserves in project landscapes
See Table 19 for areas by landscape

target.comment:
- An additional 300,000ha of forest/ native vegetation included in Socio Bosque programme in 2 target landscapes, and managed in accordance with project guidelines in support of wildlife conservation
- 2 municipal PAs gazette (landscapes 1 & 3); combined area of ~ 50,000ha
- Other areas remain stable

actual.comment:
By means of Ministerial Agreement No. 011 of February 26, 2014, The Ministry of Environment (MAE) declared a new protected area in the Colonso - Chalupas Biological Reserve, which covers an area of 93,246 hectares and is located in the Napo Province between the Antisana Ecological Reserve and Llanganates National Park, contributing directly to connectivity in the landscape project 3 (Cofan Bermejo - Llanganates).
The project provided support to the Decentralized Autonomous Governments (GADs) in the provinces of Carchi and Imbabura, in the process of declaring protected areas (PAs) for the GADs‚Äô subsystem, part of the National System of Protected Areas in Ecuador (SNAP). In the case of the Province of Carchi, this process included the municipalities of Tulc√°n, Huaca, Montufar and Bolivar. In this province, 16,000 hectares in the Eastern Cordillera will be used as a conservation area through ordinance of Carchi Provincial GAD. In the case of the Province of Imbabura, the Municipality of Pimampiro was included in the process of becoming a Protected Area, which is within its remit.
The project is providing support and technical advice to the Decentralized Autonomous Municipal Government of Francisco de Orellana (El Coca), in the process of declaring a protected forest of 200 hectares, located to the south of the city, in the CocaZoo municipal zoo zone of influence. The project will directly support the gathering of information about wildlife, which will be used as input in the process of declaring the protected area.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Threat Reduction
O3. Reductions in levels of illegal bushmeat trade in three target landscapes (1, 3, 4) covering 5,289,900ha

baseline.comment:
In 2011, ? 19 t/yr of bushmeat were traded in Pompeya market, obtained from Yasuni NP; in San Pedro, market (Yasuni Biosphere Reserve) 1.5t/year sold over 2 sample years and in Coca market, Puerto Francisco de Orellana, 1.7t/year over 4 sample years
See Table 19

target.comment:
Quantities of bushmeat sold in markets in 3 target landscapes (1, 3 and 4) are reduced by 30% over the project period
See Table 19 for explanation

actual.comment:
The records on the retention of bush meat for 2014 were systematized and analyzed, and these were reported to the Wildlife Unit of DNB, from which technical and administrative recommendations were issued so as to improve the registration process.
Information was collected relating to the National System of Honorary Wildlife Inspectors, whose members contribute to the prevention of wildlife trafficking, including bush meat. Relevant information will be developed and used for the implementation of proposals for management and sustainability in protected areas during subsequent periods.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Enabling environment:
O4. Increases in levels and sustainability of financial resources in support of the sustainable management of wildlife

baseline.comment:
- SNAP financial gap in 2011 was $2,469,806 (basic scenario) and $4,602,300 (optimal scenario), with no budget specifically earmarked for wildlife conservation and management.
-
None of the 12 Decentralised Governments (GADs) covering the Project landscapes have specific budgetary provisions in support of the conservation and management of threatened wildlife.

target.comment:
- MAE covering salary costs of the 10 wildlife technicians in 5 target landscapes ($75,684/year total).
- SNAP budget has specific earmarking for wildlife conservation
- 5 GADs have allocated budget to replicate livelihood production activities in additional communities in target landscapes with the aim of reducing pressures on wildlife.
- 12 GADs in Project landscapes have specific budgetary provisions for wildlife conservation/ management.

actual.comment:
MAE is covering the salaries of five technical specialists in the wildlife area (three biologists and two veterinarians), thus supporting the management of the project throughout 2014,.The corresponding national contribution was $ 331,232.28, and will be $ 150,068.54 in 2015, which shows a considerable annual increase in national spending on the project‚Äôs implementation.
A representative of the Executive Directorate of the Consortium of Autonomous Provincial Governments of Ecuador (CONGOPE) forms part of the Landscapes ‚Äì Wildlife Project Committee.
The GAD of the Province of Imbabura has assigned an amount of approximately $ 50,000 to activities related to the management of wildlife in the province in 2015.
The document for the prioritization of the project was prepared and presented by the National Secretariat of Planning and Development (SENPLADES), which will have fiscal resources until completion.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Enabling environment:
O5. Existence and application of normative instruments regarding conservation and management of wildlife

baseline.comment: TULAS is under reform regarding normative framework for conservation and management of wildlife.

target.comment: The respective normative framework in TULAS includes illegal trafficking, commercial hunting, sport hunting norms and is under application nationwide

actual.comment:
The project contributes to the reform Unified Text of Secondary Legislation from the Ministry of Environment (TULSMA, for its acronym in Spanish) previously called TULAS and documents of the Organic Environmental Code (COA) , with respect to issues of conservation and management of wildlife, including the issues of trafficking and commercial hunting carried out. These instruments are currently in a phase prior to publication and entry into effect.
Along with the DNB Wildlife Unit, this project made contributions to combat issues in the illegal trade of wildlife and commercial hunting through the law called the Organic Criminal Code (COIP), which has already been in effect since August 2014, and which in Article 247, expressly defines crimes against wild flora and fauna.
To this end, the Official Gazette No. 385 Ministerial Decree No. 261 published in November 2014, prohibits hunting in the country, considering it an illegal activity, except for subsistence, whose rules are currently in development. Current regulation do not codify on sports hunting.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description:
Replication:
O6. Increases in number of PAs and adjacent landscapes nationwide with planning and management instruments incorporating project models and lessons learnt project
(see notes in Table 19)

baseline.comment: 0 (no models or lessons learnt have been generated)

target.comment: 2 PAs and 2 Provincial GADs (other than those directly targeted by the project) have planning and management instruments which incorporate the models and lessons learnt which are generated through the project

actual.comment:
During the reporting period, the project has coordinated actions for the development of local planning instruments and support the declaration of new protected areas (21000 ha) with the Decentralized Autonomous Governments (GADs) in the provinces of Imbabura and Carchi, and the strengthening capacity for the personal at the protected areas for which the project developed a protocol for the Biological Monitoring of Wildlife; to this end, the administration of the Yasuni and Antinsana National Parks, have decided to adopt and implement this model for monitoring their areas of work which contribute to the management of wildlife, criteria that form part of systematization processes, automation and repeatability at institutional level, since in the future they will seek to have these efforts indexed in scientific journals.
Regarding the relationship with provincial GADs, the consultancy: "Assessment of the Tenure of the Conservation Area Cordillera Oriental and its Roadmap in the Province of Carchi" now comes into effect, providing input for SNAP record entry and its future declaration as a protected area.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: PAs contribute effectively to the conservation of threatened wildlife

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1.1 Increases in sustainability of extraction of bushmeat for subsistence consumption, in one community in Pambilar WR (Landscape 1), one in Cof√°n Bermejo ER (Landscape 3) and three in Yasuni NP (Landscape 4).
See note in Table 19 on how sustainability will be defined

baseline.comment:
In 2012, 14,680kg of subsistence bushmeat was extracted in three Kichwa communities.
See notes in Table 19

target.comment:
Plans for sustainable subsistence hunting under implementation (including controls for hunting in source areas; breeding females and of juvenile individuals) in:
- 3 communities in Cuyabeno-Yasuni
- 1 community in Pambilar WR
- 1 community in Cof√°n Bermejo ER
See notes in Table 19

actual.comment: The project conducted a study regarding the "Diagnosis of Socio-economic Development of Communities Affected by the Project", thanks to which the five communities are being identified where they will work on the development and implementation of community plans for subsistence hunting.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 1.2 Increases in numbers of community plans and norms applied to wildlife management (e.g. types and timing of offtake) in target landscapes

baseline.comment: Six Kichwa communities Landscape 4 are applying community norms and management plans for the regulation of subsistence hunting, covering 81,523ha

target.comment:
17 communities covering ? 230,000ha in 3 target landscapes applying community norms for wildlife management
Area estimate is based on average per community in landscape 4 at present, to be confirmed at project start

actual.comment: Similarly, using the result of the study of the socio-economic diagnosis, the identification process of these communities will signal the beginning of work on the implementation of policies and plans for the management of wildlife, whose area is being defined in a participatory way and adapted to the realities of the communities selected.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
1.3 Increase in wildlife management effectiveness index
See notes in Table 19

baseline.comment: Average total score for 7 target PAs 30.29 out of a possible 76

target.comment: Average total score for 7 target PAs 58.43 out of a possible 76

actual.comment:
The overall average for the reporting period is 13.57.
The values for Year 1 are lower than those indicated in the project document is that the matrixes for year 0 were completed without the basic information needed to do so accurately. Once the 1st year of the project was completed, it was possible to calculate the value standards using more reliable data. This is not a "setback" in terms of wildlife management, but rather an adjustment to the reality of the current status of its management. From the 2nd year of the project, there will be a clear improvement in terms of the effectiveness of wildlife management.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 1.4 Increases in ratings of Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool in 7 target PAs.

baseline.comment: Average total score for 7 target PAs 37.71 out of a possible 102

target.comment: Average total score for 7 target PAs: 52 out of a possible 102

actual.comment: This will be measured by the project's MidTerm period.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
1.5 Increases in capacities of PA staff in relation to the conservation and management of threatened wildlife
See notes in Table 19

baseline.comment: Personnel of three PAs (6 park guards in Pambilar, 2 in Cofan Bermejo and 9 in El √Ångel) have specific capacities and knowledge related to wildlife management and conservation.

target.comment:
-Two additional technical personnel/ target PA trained and assigned specific wildlife functions
-Provisions exist in MAE for the long-term institutionalization of these capacities.

actual.comment:
Between April and December 2014, through DNB, MAE added 10 specialized technicians to the wildlife project. From January 2015, five technicians remain (three biologists and two wildlife veterinarians) who support project management.
The project began the process of training the MAE technical staff at headquarters and central provinces, in different fields related to the management and conservation of wildlife. Training topics have included: i) conflicts in people ‚Äì fauna management; ii) biological monitoring of wildlife at the landscape scale; iii) crimes against wildlife; iv) socio - environmental conflict management; v) environmental management rights, vi) multiculturalism policy, and vii) a pilot program for environmental education for rangers in World Heritage Natural Areas of Ecuador (PANE), specifically focused on people - wildlife conflict management and wildlife trafficking.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Management of non-PA areas in 5 target landscapes contributes effectively to the conservation of threatened wildlife.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 2.1 Increases in # of Descentralised Governments (GAD) in target landscapes with planning, regulatory and normative instruments (and associated budgetary provisions) that incorporate specific provisions for reducing pressures on threatened wildlife

baseline.comment:
-0/12 target landscape GADS have Territorial Land Use Plans (TLUP) that incorporate specific provisions for reducing pressures on wildlife
-TLUP of Orellana Municipality includes specific objectives related to wildlife conservation.
0 provincial GADs in project landscapes have or apply regulatory or normative instruments in relation to illegal hunting and trafficking of wildlife

target.comment: 5/12 GADs in target landscape with TLUP that incorporate specific provisions for reducing pressures on wildlife, and 5 (1 per landscape) apply ordinances which regulate and sanction illegal hunting and trafficking of wildlife, harmonized with the national norm, with associated budgetary provisions.

actual.comment:
The project contributed to the review, comments and technical suggestions on incorporating specific measures to reduce pressure on wildlife in the document "Guidelines for Preparation of Development Plans and Zoning of the Autonomous Governments" prepared by the National Secretariat of Planning and Development (SENPLADES). The suggestions given were accepted and incorporated into the final document.
An inter-institutional cooperation agreement was signed between the Ministry of Environment and the Municipal GAD of Orellana, so as to establish mutual commitments for the management of wildlife. The support is part of the project by providing technical advice and veterinarian inputs to animals kept in the zoo of Orellana, at the same time they offer us a physical space and basic services to provide a service to animals. In addition, it is proposed to make joint campaigns of sterilization of domestic animals, which affects wildlife found around the area.
In meetings held with the representative of CONGOPE, activities were planned to improve the capabilities of the technical environmental management of various provincial GADs. These meetings include a focus on specific criteria for the proper management of wildlife.
Through analysis of the Socio - Economic diagnosis, information on the current state of the regulatory function of the GADs, as well as their policy instruments, is being organized in order to reduce pressure on wildlife.
Hiring a specialist for the relationship with GADs will also strengthen activities in this area.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2.2 Increase in the percentage of detected illegal actions (transporting wildlife and bushmeat, or selling bushmeat in markets) in pilot landscapes that are successfully sanctioned.

baseline.comment: To be established by midterm once the norms and fines are re- or defined. Currently no specific control/inspection points to detect infringements, no detailed sanctions defined for wildlife offences, and the fines used are not appropriate

target.comment: -  50% increase on baseline % of successful sanctions.

actual.comment:
The project team developed the database relating to administrative and criminal procedures related to crimes against wildlife at a national level, initiated by MAE in 2014, allowing to identify critical points, technical and legal barriers in administrative and criminal proceedings carried out by the Ministry of Environment, this information will be entered into the Information System Biodiversity (SIB).
The new Criminal Code (COIP), which came into effect in August 2014, explicitly defines crimes against wildlife and establishes a clear penalty system.
Following MAE¬¥s environmental policies, a Wildlife DNB Unit, prepared a "Proposal for the Regulation of Hunting and Local Wildlife Operations in Ecuador," which will also be included in the reform proposal of TULSMA.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 2.3 Reduction in detected incidence of wildlife and bushmeat trade per unit of effort at pilot enforcement points.

baseline.comment: To be determined when enforcement points are set up

target.comment: -  50% reduction in detection/unit effort, due to the deterrent effect of the enforcement points.

actual.comment:
Technicians systematize project data and periodically analyze records of wildlife retention (including bushmeat), which are reported to the Wildlife DNB Unit, enabling information to be monitored and trends to be detected.
The project provided technical support to the Forestry and Wildlife Stations, regarding the retention of bushmeat and wildlife in Santa Cecilia (Sucumbios Province), Baeza (Napo Province), El Coca (Orellana Province) and Mera (Pastaza Province).
The project contributed to the purchase of equipment required for the transportation and proper management of confiscated wildlife as a result of checks on illegal trafficking. Delivery is made to several of MAE‚Äôs provincial departments. The team of biologists and veterinarians and the Wildlife DNB Project Unit also have access to this equipment.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 2.4 Increases in # families in communities adjoining PAs in target landscapes, participating in livelihood /¬¥productive activities demonstrated to reduce pressures on wildlife

baseline.comment:
To be determined, once target families are identified,
See notes in Table 19

target.comment:
- 20% of families in 7 communities adjoining PAs target landscapes 1,2, 3,4,5
-
See notes in Table 19

actual.comment: Based on the study of the socio-economic diagnosis, communities are being identified (as well as the number of families) who participate in subsistence and / or production activities, so as to reduce pressure on wildlife. Communities with connections to the Small Grants Program (PPD) and Socio Bosque Program will be prioritized.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 2.5 Reductions in frequency of conflicts between fauna and agricultural and/or ranching activities, in all 5 target landscapes

baseline.comment:
Numbers of cases in which wild fauna was reported to have attacked cattle:
- Andean bears: 21 in Carchi (2009- 2013), 1 in Tungurahua (2013), 45 in Imbabura (2011-2013)
- Jaguars: 6 in Morono Santiago (2013), 1 in Imbabura (2011-2013)

target.comment: 50% reduction in frequency of reported attacks by wild fauna on cattle, due to awareness raising and the introduction of improved management practices for agriculture and ranching

actual.comment:
The project organized the "1st. National Symposium on People ‚Äì Fauna Conflict Management and Wildlife Trafficking ", which aimed to create opportunities to exchange experiences, awareness and knowledge related to these issues and jointly find ways to manage these problems more effectively.
The project, run in conjunction with the Wildlife DNB Unit, proposed that livestock deaths caused by attacks from wild animals, will be covered by an Agricultural Insurance, (Agroseguros) provided by the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock, Aquaculture and Fisheries (MAGAP). This proposal was discussed and finally accepted for implementation. In its initial phase, only cattle are included.
10 people - fauna conflict maps of vulnerability were developed and validated in five landscape sites.

Ecuador no tiene ning√∫n centro de tratamiento y/√≥ eliminaci√≥n de los PCB. 5. Las directrices existentes para la gesti√≥n de PCB son limitadas y no cubren todo el ciclo de vida. 6. result.title: Objective
result.description: To promote the sound management of PCB contaminated oil, equipment, sites and wastes in Ecuador

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Quantity of PCB (liquids and solids) destroyed in the project period (2013-2017).
Quantity of PCBs stored in an environmentally sound manner.

baseline.comment:
Estimated inventory of 1,400 MT of PCBs.
National inventory outdated and only estimate.

target.comment:
750 MT of PCBs (equipment, oils and wastes) disposed of in an environmentally sound manner.
All PCB inventories stored in an environmentally sound manner

actual.comment:
None of the 750 MT have been disposed of yet, for that, an updated inventory of the quantity of PCB is needed. The Project is developing a National System for Inventory and Monitoring of PCB (NSIM-PCB) - a computer program that all companies are required to use to report on the progress of their inventories. The system is expected to be operational by January 2016.
Throughout 2014, the Project visited all electric companies to gather data and update the inventory. The results indicated that only 15% of the total number of electrical equipment in the country have been inventoried.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of environmental, health and customs authorities personnel trained to monitor compliance of Stockholm Convention requirements and norms.

baseline.comment: Environmental, health, customs and electric sector authorities personnel do not have the knowledge and training to execute control and monitoring of the PCB inventory in the county.

target.comment: 30 officials of the environmental, health, customs and electric sector authorities trained to control the commerce, storage, transport, treatment and final disposal of PCBs.

actual.comment: The project has trained 193 officials (6.4 times more people were trained than initially targeted) from the environmental, customs and electric sector to control commerce, storage, transport, treatment and final disposal of PCBs. Training on environmentally Sound Management (ESM) of PCB was conducted during three training events in the reporting period of July 1, 2014 to June 30 2015. The project has already achieved its target.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of environmental, health and customs authorities personnel trained to monitor compliance of Stockholm Convention requirements and norms.

baseline.comment: Environmental, health, customs and electric sector authorities personnel do not have the knowledge and training to execute control and monitoring of the PCB inventory in the county.

target.comment: 1 Norm developed and validated

actual.comment: A Regulation (Procedures for Integrated and Environmentally Sound Management of Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs) in Ecuador) has been drafted and sent for public consultation. The Project held the final public consultation process on June 2015. Currently the regulation is under revision by the Legal Department, prior to approval and signature by the Minister of the Environment, which is expected to be obtained in October 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of environmental, health and customs authorities personnel trained to monitor compliance of Stockholm Convention requirements and norms.

baseline.comment: Environmental, health, customs and electric sector authorities personnel do not have the knowledge and training to execute control and monitoring of the PCB inventory in the county.

target.comment: 4 guidelines/manuals developed by the end of the project.

actual.comment:
The "Manual for the Handling of PCBs in the Ecuadorian Electric Sector", which was developed in 2012 by the Ministry of Environment of Ecuador and Agency of Regulation and Control of the Electric Sector (ARCONEL), is a useful tool used by the PCB Project for training workshops and is being used by electrical companies to comply with PCB adequate management. The Manual is being updated by ARCONEL and will be revised by the PCB Project prior to its publication.
In addition, the Project has developed two (2) technical guides, which are approved by MAE in its technical text and need to be validated in its visual part by the communication department prior to printing. The guides are: technical guide for general information of POPs and technical guide for environmentally sound management (ESM) of PCB.
Other guidelines are being planned, such as, the occupational safety procedures for handling of dielectric oil and electrical equipment with PCB.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of safe PCB management and disposal options.

baseline.comment: Ecuador does not have any treatment/disposal facility for PCBs.

target.comment: At least one treatment/disposal alternative in operation at the end of the project, if proven cost effective compared to export option.

actual.comment: Once an updated and more complete inventory data is available, the Project may have better tools to choose a treatment/disposal alternative and compared it to the export option.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of companies of the electrical sector trained and implementing the new regulatory guidelines.

baseline.comment: Existing guidelines for PCB management are limited and do not cover the entire life cycle.

target.comment: 75% of the existing electrical sector companies trained and implementing the new regulatory guidelines.

actual.comment: During the public consultation process of the PCB Regulation developed with support of the Project, there has been significant collaboration with many State organizations, including environment, petroleum, mines, health, customs, electric, and port authorities as well as PCB holders, which has led to better awareness on among PCB issues. Once the Regulation is officially published, the Project will train all involved sectors in its compliance.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of inspectors/enforcement officers trained to monitor compliance of national laws/norms on PCB management.

baseline.comment: The environmental regulating authorities have limited knowledge about PCB management.

target.comment: 40 maintenance and other personnel at PCB holders trained in safe PCB management.

actual.comment:
The Project has developed a training plan for the electric sector which begun implementation in 2014. Through three (3) training workshops in 2014 and two (2) training workshops until June 2015, with the topic of general information on POPs and ESM of PCB, the Project has trained 193 persons from various public and private sectors, 90 of these persons were maintenance personnel from electrical companies.
The project is visiting the majority of Universities in the country (so far, 7 Universities have been visited), giving a 1-2 hour conference on POPs and PCBs to students and teachers and informing them about the PCB inventory program. Up until June 2015, the Project has reached 290 students and teachers.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Number of inspectors/enforcement officers trained to monitor compliance of national laws/norms on PCB management.

baseline.comment: The environmental regulating authorities have limited knowledge about PCB management.

target.comment: 10 inspectors/enforcement officers trained to enforce compliance of national laws/norms on PCB management.

actual.comment:
During the public consultation process of the PCB Regulation developed with support of the Project, there has been significant collaboration with many State organizations, including environment, petroleum, mines, health, customs, electric, and port authorities as well as PCB holders, which has led to better awareness on PCB issues.
Once the Regulation is officially published, the Project will start proper training to all involved sectors in its compliance.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Institutional capacity strengthening for sound and environmentally friendly management of PCBs.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of PCB management regulations developed and validated by regulation institutions.

baseline.comment: PCB management is not established by regulations and norms that guarantee their environmentally sound management.

target.comment: PCB management regulations and environmentally sound management norms developed and validated.

actual.comment: A Regulation (Procedures for Integrated and Environmentally Sound Management of Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs) in Ecuador), has been drafted and sent for public consultation. The Project held the final public consultation process on June 2015. Currently the regulation is under revision by the Legal Department, prior to approval and signature by the Minister of the Environment, which is expected to be obtained in October 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of electrical sector companies implementing PCB management and elimination plans to meet national goals by 2020.

baseline.comment: The Constitution and the national development plan establish the elimination of PCBs but there are not regulations for it.

target.comment: National PCB management and elimination plan up to 2020 approved and in implementation process.

actual.comment: The National Plan for PCB Management and Elimination has not yet been developed; this is planned by 2017, once an updated and more complete inventory data is available.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of inspectors trained to conduct site visits for the verification of compliance to the PCB management regulations.

baseline.comment: The regulating institutions do not have the trained inspectors that can evaluate the environmentally sound management of PCBs and compliance of its corresponding regulations.

target.comment: At least 10 inspectors trained in PCB management evaluation and enforcement in the environmental, electric and health regulating institutions.

actual.comment:
94 officials from many institutions including environment, petroleum, mines, health, customs, electric, and port authorities, have been trained in ESM of PCB during all the events held by the Project, these officials should be prepared to verify compliance of good practices for PCB management.
During the public consultation process of the PCB Regulation developed with support of the Project, there has been significant collaboration with many State organizations, which has led to better awareness on PCB issues. Once the Regulation is officially published, the Project will start proper training to all involved sectors in its compliance.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of inspections completed during project implementation (2013-2017).

baseline.comment: Limited institutional capacity to present proper reports to the Stockholm Convention.

target.comment: Inspections made by regulating institutions to each electrical company per semester.

actual.comment: All electric companies require an environmental license for its operation, in order to obtain a license, the company has to have management plan for oil and equipment containing PCBs. ARCONEL, which is the institution in charge of processing and issuing these licenses, performs audits of such plans two times a year or when the environmental authority so requires.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Number of reports to the Stockholm Convention presented on time and in an effective manner.
Number of inventories updated on line with information from the electrical sector companies with PCBs identified and eliminated.

baseline.comment: Limited institutional capacity to present proper reports to the Stockholm Convention.

target.comment: PCB inventory updated including equipment, oil and waste, identified and the amounts of tons that have been eliminated, incorporated into the monitoring information system.

actual.comment:
In 2014 the Project support the country¬¥s Technical Focal Point for the Stockholm Convention, to report on the progress of inventory and the amount of PCBs eliminated. The report was based in preliminary data, because progress had not been made at that time in the inventory and no PCBs has been eliminated.
The Project is developing a National System for Inventory and Monitoring of PCB (NSIM-PCB) - a computer program that all companies are required to use to report on the progress of their inventories. The system is expected to be operational by January 2016.
Throughout 2014, the Project visited all electric companies to gather data and update the inventory. The results indicated that only 15% of the total number of electrical equipment in the country have been inventoried.
Three soil characterizations for contaminated sites were performed in 2014. One, presented contaminated soil above 750 ppm of PCBs, the volume of contaminated soil was determined in line with the UNIDO technical guide POPs: Contaminated Site Investigation and Management Toolkit. All contaminated soil has been properly stored and registered in the inventory for future treatment or disposal.
In 2015, the Project has been assessing 13 additional sites for possible PCB contamination. According to preliminary results, 7 sites have been prioritized for further analysis (phase II) to determine the volume of contaminated soil.
In 2014, with the aim of speed the inventory of PCB, the Project purchased and donated to the Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy (MEER), a gas chromatograph with ECD column (electron capture detector). This equipment allowed the establishment of an agreement between the two ministries, whereby the MEER agreed to double its analytical capacity (from 200 to 400 samples per month), accredit ISO 17025 the method of analysis (with the quality agency in Ecuador) and reduce, in 35%, the cost of the analysis of each oil sample, exclusively for electric utilities.
In addition, with the support of the Ecuadorian Accreditation Service (SAE), five (5) laboratories of state universities and the laboratory form MEER, were trained in the method of analysis for determination of PCB in oil samples and obtaining ISO 17025 accreditation. Currently, one laboratory has already obtained its accreditation and another laboratory is in process of accreditation and expects to obtain it this year.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of publications and activities developed under the awareness raising campaign.

baseline.comment: General public and private sectors are not aware of the risks to health and the environment from inadequate PCB management practices.

target.comment: Environmentally sound management of PCB training manual elaborated and implemented in parallel to a training plan for electrical sector companies.

actual.comment:
As a training manual for workshops, the Project uses the "Manual for the Handling of PCBs in the Ecuadorian Electric Sector", which was developed in 2012 by the Ministry of Environment of Ecuador and ARCONEL. Electrical companies to comply with PCB adequate management also use this Manual. The Manual is being updated by ARCONEL and will be revised by the PCB Project prior to its publication.
The Project has also developed a training plan for the electric sector which begun implementation in 2014. Up until June 2015, the Project has trained 193 persons from various public sectors, as well as private and public entities.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of publications and activities developed under the awareness raising campaign.

baseline.comment: General public and private sectors are not aware of the risks to health and the environment from inadequate PCB management practices.

target.comment: Awareness raising campaign among public and private sectors involved in chemicals management on proper PCB management.

actual.comment:
The Project started a campaign in 2015 for awareness raising on POPs and PCBs, this activity includes lectures in the main Universities in the country: Up until June 2015, seven (7) Universities have been visited and 290 students and teachers have been informed about these topics.
In addition, in partnership with the National Secretary of Education (SENESCYT), the Project has started a campaign to facilitate economic resources to University projects related to POPs and PCBs (determination of POPs and PCBs in soil, water and biota, inventory of PCBs in the mining industry, PCBs treatment, etc.). These projects will be evaluated by SENESCYT and the PCB Project prior to be accepted for financing.
During all training events organized by the PCB project, participants are given a leaflet and a notebook with information on PCB. These materials were developed by the project and approved by MAE before being printed. Both the leaflet and the notebook are visual material and serve to attendees to retain information and replicate it in their respective institutions.
Furthermore, the Project is developing a video showing the steps to an environmentally sound management of PCB and showing the main achievements and future activities of the Project. This video will be made available to all public with the objective to raise awareness and to provide basic knowledge and contacts to get more information if needed.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of electrical sector companies with PCB management plans, developed and presented to the CONELEC/MAE for approval.

baseline.comment: There is a lack of a national environmental management and elimination plan that will be a guide for the electrical companies to budget and program activities regarding their PCB issues.

target.comment: Technical guidelines for PCB management approved and in process of implementation.

actual.comment:
In 2013, before the start of the PCB Project, all the electrical companies in Ecuador presented their PCB Management Plans to ARCONEL (former CONELEC), all of which were approved. This indicates that all companies are working based on their respectively approved Plans and based on the Manual for the Handling of PCBs in the Ecuadorian Electric Sector, also developed by ARCONEL in 2012.
In order to complement the information that electrical companies have, the Project has developed two (2) technical guides, which are approved by MAE in its technical text and need to be validated in its visual part by the communication department prior to printing. The guides are: technical guidelines for general information of POPs and technical guidelines for the environmentally sound management (ESM) of PCB.
Additional guidelines are being planned for 2016, such as, the occupational safety procedures for handling of dielectric oil and electrical equipment with PCB.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of occupational health and safety trainers to implement guidelines. Number of occupational health and safety guidelines issued and implemented by the electrical companies.

baseline.comment: Occupational health and safety issues are important when evaluating potential risk for workers who have may have been exposed to PCBs in the past and to prevent future incidents.

target.comment: Occupational health and safety regulations for personnel exposed to PCB contaminated equipment, oil and waste prepared and in process of implementation.

actual.comment: The Regulation on PCB previously mentioned, contains norms on occupational safety and health aspects for personnel coming in contact with PCB-contaminated equipment, oil and wastes. The Regulation will be official in the coming months.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of alternative PCB disposal options evaluated with a feasibility study.

baseline.comment: There is no differentiation, because of the limited inventory, between high and low concentrations of PCB to decide on alternative options.

target.comment: Feasibility studies completed to determine technically and economically viable in-country and out-of-country alternatives for the elimination of PCB contaminated equipment, oil and wastes.

actual.comment:
The feasibility study will start once the NSIM-PCB system is fully operational. However, the project is investigating some alternatives of destruction for PCB, one of which is the co-processing in cement kilns for which, the Project has met with two leading cement plants in Ecuador, to determine if it is possible to co-processed oil with more than 50 ppm of PCBs in their kilns. If the test is positive, this could be a local alternative treatment for PCB oil.
The project has also coordinated visits to Ecuador for the months of July and August with two European companies of incineration of PCB at high temperatures. The idea is that these companies can visit the PCB equipment and oil storage sites, check the approximate amounts of existing waste and provide an approximate cost of disposing of these stocks in their incineration plants.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of alternative PCB disposal options evaluated with a feasibility study.

baseline.comment: There is no differentiation, because of the limited inventory, between high and low concentrations of PCB to decide on alternative options.

target.comment: Identification of process to be implemented for elimination of PCB contaminated equipment, oils and waste.

actual.comment: Planned after the feasibility study has been completed.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Environmentally sound storage and disposal of PCB waste.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of electrical sector companies with a management plan for the temporary storage of PCB contaminated equipment, oil and waste presented to regulating authorities (CONELEC/MAE) for approval and being implemented.

baseline.comment: Currently, there are no technical standards for temporary storage of PCB inventories.

target.comment: Technical guidelines for temporary storage facilities for PCB inventories approved and implemented.

actual.comment: The technical guidelines for the ESM of PCBs, developed and approved with support of the project, contain a section on storage, which is in accordance with international standards and the Ecuadorian Standard NTE INEN 22:66-2013 (Transport, storage and handling of hazardous chemicals), where the conditions for warehouses for hazardous materials are prescribed.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of electrical sector companies with a management plan for the temporary storage of PCB contaminated equipment, oil and waste presented to regulating authorities (CONELEC/MAE) for approval and being implemented.

baseline.comment: Currently, there are no technical standards for temporary storage of PCB inventories.

target.comment: Environmentally sound temporary storage of PCB contaminated equipment; oil and waste are implemented in the electrical sector companies.

actual.comment:
In 2013, before the start of the PCB all the electrical companies in Ecuador presented their PCB Managements plans to ARCONEL (former CONELEC). These plans included proper storage of equipment, oil and wastes containing PCBs.
The Project also visited all electric companies and most of their equipment and oil storage sites in 2014. It was observed that some companies have built adequate warehouses, however, many companies still have precarious and inadequate storage sites for hazardous materials. Therefore, the PCB Project is facilitating agreements in between large and small PCB holders, where large holder store the PCB equipment of small holders (example: PCB equipment from the Galapagos, will be stored at the Guayaquil electric company until destruction alternatives have been developed and approved).
In addition, the PCB Project is analyzing the possibility of building a warehouse that complies with all requirements and conditions for adequate storage, which can be used by all electric companies that lack their own storage facility.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
One or a combination of PCB disposal options identified and in tender process for selection of servicers.
Number of tons of PCB contaminated equipment; oil and waste are eliminated during the project (2013-2017).

baseline.comment: Ecuador lacks of in-country options for PCB disposal and only the exporting of the equipment, oil and waste with a very high cost associated is available.

target.comment: Technically and economically viable PCB elimination option identified and in process of implementation.

actual.comment:
A feasibility study will start once the NSIM-PCB system is fully operational.
The project has also developed a pilot test for PCB elimination with ECOSAFE product. The company Benimex in the presence of staff, appointed as an observer, by the Ministry of Environment, performed the test. Upon completion of the test and after performing the analysis, it was found that PCBs only moved from the liquid phase to a semi-solid phase, proving that the elimination of PCB with ECOSAFE not possible.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
One or a combination of PCB disposal options identified and in tender process for selection of servicers.
Number of tons of PCB contaminated equipment; oil and waste are eliminated during the project (2013-2017).

baseline.comment: There is not a defined disposal plan for the fulfillment of the country¬¥s requirements under the Stockholm Convention or its national regulations.

target.comment: National disposal plan developed, approved and electrical sector companies committed to its implementation.

actual.comment:
In 2017, the Project will begin to elaborate the National Disposal Plan in line with the elimination options identified during the feasibility study and experiences gained from a PCB disposal pilot project.
This plan will be elaborated in coordination with ARCONEL.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of tons of PCB contaminated equipment, oil and waste identified in the Galapagos Islands.

baseline.comment: The Galapagos Islands have electrical equipment that could be potentially contaminated with PCBs.

target.comment: Pilot project for identification and removal of PCB contaminated equipment, oil and waste from Galapagos developed and implemented.

actual.comment:
The Project has completed an inventory of all decommissioned equipment (222) on the Galapagos Islands. Samples were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) and only one equipment was reported to contain a PCB concentration greater than 50 ppm of PCBs, this equipment has been properly stored.
During 2015, the Project will complete the inventory on the Galapagos Islands by sampling and analyzing all public and private in-line equipment (663). Once the results of this inventory are available, a decision can be made about the best alternative for treatment or elimination of PCBs.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of tons of identified inventory is removed from the Galapagos island.

baseline.comment: There is a need to develop an inventory and elimination plan for them.

target.comment: Disposal plan for Galapagos PCB inventory developed approved and budgeted.

actual.comment:
Due to the low volume of oil and small quantity of PCB contaminated equipment expected to be present in the Galapagos, a valid alternative could be to transport wastes to the continent for appropriate storage until a final decision is taken.
The equipment, oil and wastes contaminated with PCB from Galapagos will be included in a pilot project of elimination, along with PCB containing wastes from other holders.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of tons of PCB contaminated equipment, oil and waste eliminated.

baseline.comment: Ecuador has committed to the disposal of 750 metric tons of PCBs during the project.

target.comment: Disposal of 750 metric tons of the existing PCB inventory of contaminated equipment, oil and waste.

actual.comment:
The amount of 750 metric tons of equipment, oil and wastes contaminated with PCB, which the project initially targeted to dispose of, appears to be overestimated. Based on GC results carried out by many electric companies and by the PCB Project, it can be concluded that the total amount of contaminated oil and equipment in the country will be lower than the one stated in the preliminary inventory (1,500 metric tons).
Once updated and accurate inventory data become available, it may be determine the amount of PCB for disposal.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during the project implementation.

baseline.comment: No documents in baseline situation.

target.comment: 4 Quarterly Operational Reports submitted to UNDP each year.

actual.comment: Instead of quarterly reports, and as per request of the UNDP Country Office, the Project has been presenting monthly Operational Reports.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during the project implementation.

baseline.comment: No documents in baseline situation.

target.comment: 1 annual APR/PIR submitted to UNDP each year.

actual.comment: This is the first PIR that PCB Project is preparing.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during the project implementation.

baseline.comment: No documents in baseline situation.

target.comment: 1 Mid-term evaluation.

actual.comment: Mid-term evaluation is planned for 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during the project implementation.

baseline.comment: No documents in baseline situation.

target.comment: 1 Final evaluation.

actual.comment: Final evaluation is planned for 2017.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during the project implementation.

baseline.comment: No documents in baseline situation.

target.comment: MTE and FE must include lessons learned section and a strategy for dissemination of project results.

actual.comment: The TE and MTE will include a lessons learned section and a strategy for dissemination of project results

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: a) Incremento porcentual en el gasto p√∫blico local para prevenir la violencia contra las mujeres, los j√≥venes, los pueblos ind√≠genas, los afroecuatorianos y los refugiados. b) Aumento progresivo de oportunidades de medios de subsistencia para las mujeres, los j√≥venes, los refugiados, los pueblos ind√≠genas y afroecuatorianos (especialmente las mujeres) en las zonas rurales y urbanas de las provincias de Sucumb√≠os y Esmeraldas. c) N√∫mero de cursos de capacitaci√≥n dirigidos a j√≥venes, incluidos los refugiados, procedentes de comunidades con altos niveles de inseguridad. d) La agenda de prevenci√≥n de conflictos se incluye progresivamente en los procesos de planificaci√≥n local. e) N√∫mero de comit√©s de di√°logo establecidos localmente. f) Aumento progresivo de la participaci√≥n pol√≠tica y social de los j√≥venes (especialmente las mujeres, los pueblos ind√≠genas y afroecuatorianos).

baseline.comment: a) Un foro interinstitucional contra la trata de personas no est√° operativo. b) Baja inversi√≥n p√∫blica en materia de prevenci√≥n de violencia contra las mujeres. c) Insuficientes espacios de di√°logo y participaci√≥n para la populaci√≥n en situaci√≥n de vulnerabilidad. d) Altos niveles de desempleo, subempleo y empleo informal para la poblaci√≥n en situaci√≥n de vulnerabilidad. e) Los procesos de planificaci√≥n no incorporan enfoques de cohesi√≥n social y de la resoluci√≥n pac√≠fica de los conflictos.

target.comment: a) Se har√° operativo un foro interinstitucional contra la trata de personas. b) Se llevar√°n a cabo cursos dirigidos a personal de seguridad, salud y educaci√≥n sobre la trata de personas, reclutamiento forzado de menores y protecci√≥n de v√≠ctimas. c) Se efectuar√° un monitoreo participativo sobre la situaci√≥n de la trata de personas y el reclutamiento forzado de menores. d) Se confirmar√° un acuerdo con el Gobierno para extender cursos de capacitaci√≥n profesional para j√≥venes. e) Se trabajar√° con peque√±os empresarios para crear oportunidades para la generaci√≥n de ingresos y la integraci√≥n social. f) Se realizar√°n cursos de capacitaci√≥n sobre la planificaci√≥n sensible al conflicto. g) Se realizar√°n cursos de capacitaci√≥n sobre la prevenci√≥n y mediaci√≥n de conflictos. h) Se capacitar√°n adolescentes en pr√°cticas de resoluci√≥n pac√≠fica de conflictos.

actual.comment: Debido a una reforma insitucional en la contraparte principal del Programa, no fue posible iniciar las actividades planificadas en la fecha inicialmente prevista. En noviembre 2014 se conform√≥ la Unidad de Coordinaci√≥n del Programa y en diciembre 2014 se envi√≥ un primer informe consolidado al UNFHS con informaci√≥n relacionada al tema insitucional arriba se√±alado.

target.comment: a) Se har√° operativo un foro interinstitucional contra la trata de personas. b) Se generar√°n planes de equipamiento para instituciones p√∫blico que capaciten o apoyen capacitaciones a poblaciones vulnerables en las zonas de intervenci√≥n. c) Generar una campa√±a de educaci√≥n p√∫blica interagencial para la prevenci√≥n de la violencia basada en g√©nero. d) Generar talleres de capacitaci√≥n en manejo de conflictos, planificados de manera participativa con actores locales. e) Organizar una feria ciudadana por el D√≠a Mundial en Contra de la Trata de Personas. f) Elaborar material edu-comunicacional para la prevenci√≥n de la trata de personas.

actual.comment: a) Se reealizaron reuniones con la mesa interinstitucional de g√©nero en Esmeraldas, en la que se acord√≥ implementar la pol√≠tica p√∫blica en contra de la trata de personas a nivel territorial. b) Se elabor√≥ un plan con el Instituto de Econom√≠a Popular y Solidaria - Zona 1 para equipar las oficinas provinciales en Esmeraldas y Sucumb√≠os; capacitar a siete organizaciones de la econom√≠a popular y solidaria distribu√≠das en ambas provincias; y, apoyar a seis emprendimientos de las mencionadas organizaciones. Adicionalmente, se gener√≥ un plan de equipamiento al local de capacitaci√≥n del Ministerio de Inclusi√≥n Econ√≥mica y Social en San Lorenzo, espacio en donde confluyen organizaciones gubernamentales y no gubernamentales que proveen capacitaci√≥n a poblaciones vulnerables en el cant√≥n (se espera capacitar aproximadamente a 415 personas en el 2016). c) Cuatro agencias implementadoras del Programa organizaron la campa√±a de diez y seis d√≠as en contra de la violencia basada en g√©nero en Lago Agrio, sensibilizando con esta acci√≥n a m√°s de 1500 personas. Como parte del proceso, se capacit√≥ a 40 l√≠deres juveniles sobre la violencia basada en g√©nero, c√≥mo identificarla y prevenirla. d) Se contrat√≥ a la Fundaci√≥n Futuro Latinoamericano para la capacitaci√≥n en manejo de conflicto, cuyos talleres se realizar√°n en el primer trismestre de 2016. e) Feria Ciudadana por el D√≠a Mundial en Contra de la Trata de Personas con la participaci√≥n de 16 instituciones p√∫blicas, dos agencias co-implementadoras. Alrededor de 1000 personas visitaron la Fer√≠a que se realiz√≥ en Lago Agrio. f) Guiones edu - comunicacionales para la prevenci√≥n de la trata de personas para difusi√≥n en radio y televisi√≥n. g) Se capacit√≥ aproximadamente a sesenta actores gubernamentales y no gubernamentales en Esmeraldas y Eloy Alfaro sobre el delito de la trata de personas y la respuesta institucional que se implementa a nivel nacional para combatirlo, asi como para asistir y proteger a las v√≠ctimas.
